TNIiE subscriber takes this method of in- A forming his friends, and the public gener- ally. that he continues to carry on the TAI LORING BUSINESS in all it's branches at his old stand near the Court House, where all who are dispo=ed to favour him with their custom. can have their garments cut and made in good style. Having acquaintance with some of the best establishments in the state, every thing relative to fashion will be speedi- ly procured. And while he feels grateful for the liberal patronage he has received, he as- sures his customers that nothing shall be wan ting on his part to give general satisfaction in future.

 0J@Particular attention given to cutting.

 STEPHEN TROWBRIDGE.

 Litchfeld, May 23, 1927. 4o

into the swollen stream, and swam through On relating his adventures, and being asked why he attempted so dangerous an experi- ment, he replied, "Why there's fine of fifty dollars if we don't deliver the mail in season, and guess they don't get it out of dad this time, and be darn'd to 'em."

with general debility under which he hss suffered for nearly year, caused his death. Ills remains were brought to this town on Saturday last; and on Sunday were followed by his surviving relations, and large com course of friends and neighbours, to the grave. It is not the lot of all men, placed in the same walks of life, tO secure to them selves the warmest love and respect of a large community. This was preeminently the case with Judge Holmes. In peeuniary concerns he has experienced prosperity and diversity; yet he was at all times the same liberal bene- factor of the poor, who were never driven away frem his door empty, and the same pat ron and friend of every enlightened and pub Ilc spirited undertaking Although in his lat- ter years he was not wealthy, yet no man was more willing to give both to public and private benefaciions than himself. The words of inspirations, ''The poor ye shall always have with you," were believed by him to con- tam an important meaning. and we believe he Eever felt disposed to evade this meaning, or shrink from the dutyswhich it enioined.- In every duty in life,--as son,--a hnsband,- tather,-a judge,-a citizen,--he manifested the same amiabe disposition, tempered with stern integrity and love for truth ,-he was atiahie, yet not cOnceited, ,-hospitable, yet not ostentatious,- charitable yet not pharisaical, -pious, yet not hypocritcal. The whole of his character may be summed up in this short, comprehensive sentence, "He was good man ;'-and although the circumstaa- ces of his death were attended with some aggravating incidents, in being called to endure pain, and suffering and death, in small pubic house, and out of the reach of those comforts and sympathies which would have consoled him in his own dwelling. his friends have the consolation of refiecting that. notwithstanding these outward affections he had peace within; and that he gave good as- surance that that Spiri. which had taught him to trust in the Redeemer, was supporting him in his passage through the dark valley and shadow of dcath.''

 In Windsor, Vt. Alden Spoener, Esq. aged 70. This gentleman was the first printer that commenced business in the state of Vermont, and for about forty years was editor of the Vermont Journal.

 ] In Brooklyn, Mrs Mary Stoddard, native of IrcIaad. aged 1O7.

 In Rowley, Mass MT Robert S. Coffin, the Boston Bard.

 At Oxford, on the 26th ult. Mrs. Re- becca Woodn, wife of William W. a. ged 7S. 1 Singular Coincidences.--Dicd at Tranent. Eng. on the 18th of Oct. 1926, Helen Man ners, & on the 16th do. Andrew, her husband. each of them at the advanced age of 80 wears. They were born in the same year, and in the same month, and were baptized on the same day. When married they were %, lived to- gether 58 years, died within q hours of each other, and were inferred on the same day, and in the same grave.

In this village, on Tuesday evening last. by Rev. MT Stone, John F. Jackson, Esq. of Newark, N. J. to Miss Elizabeth Wolcott, daughter of Frederick Wolcott, Esq.

 In Goshen, on the 18th inst. Elijah Mead, M D, of the city of New-York, to Miss Sarah Lyman, daughter of Samuel Lyman, Esq. of the former place.

 In Colchester, Rev. Thomas l.. Shipman, of Southbury, to Miss Mary T. Deming, daughter of Gen. David Deming.

 In Lyme, Col. Daniel k. Moves, to Miss Phebe Griffin Lord, daughter of the late Jo- seph Lord, Esq. In Cornwall, on the gath uIt. by the Rev. Walter Smith, Mr. Peter Richards, of Goshen, aged sS, to Miss Naomi Plaht, of Litchfeld, aged 50.

 DIED,

 In Canton, on Friday. May 10, Hon Uriel Holmes, of this village. aged 6S.--Judge Holmes left home about three weeks since, with the intention of visiting in the N. E. part of the county; and on the second day after leaving his family, was thrown from his car riage with so much violence as to break his leg in shocking manner This, together

papers have been received at N. Y. to April 10th, and Liverpool to the f7th.

 Spain.-All the reports in circulation were of a warlike character. At Madrid many laborors were employed in making cartouches, which were dispatched to Cludad Rodrigo. The Marquis of Chaves was about to make a new inroad into For tugal.

 ] A letter from Paris says, |" It is now said here, that Spain still persists in her folly. with regard to projects for invading South America, and it is asserted that the Envoy Extraordinary, NJ. D'Ofalia, is commanded to make known to the British and French Governments, that it is the in- tention of the Cabinet of Madrid to send an expedition against Mexico to establish the Infant Francisco de Paula as sove- reign. Tho Court is also said to have a still more difficult task to perform, namely, to obtain the concurrence of the Courts of the Tuilleries and St.James, to the meas ure."

 The King of Prussia, by late edict, calls upon all his subjects, under penalties, to send their children to school at cer- tain age ;-and the King of Sardinia, by an .edict of nearly the same date, forbids all persons, who do not possess certain annual income, from attending the literary institutions of his kingdom.--C Christian ] Obs. 1926;

 Beethoven, the musical composer, whose illness has frequently been mentioned, died at Viena Feb. 26.

 ConStdntinople, March 7.-The access sion of Court Gulleminot, the French am bassador, to the proposal made by England and Russia, in favour of the Greeks, is now confrmed.-It is said, however, tha, the Refs Eflendi has given him, verbally, a negative answer.

 Const0ntinople. March 1O.-Since my last letter, which announced to you the en- ergetic conduct of the new Russian Am bassador relative to the pacification of Greece, no very important change has taken place.

 l The English Ambassador, M. Straitford Canning, has yet received no answer from the Divan to his note of Feb. 9th, and as the conversations of the Refs Effendi to this minister, as we'll as to M. Ribeau- Ipierre, leave little hope of obtaining the consent of the Porte to their propositions, it is reported that the two Ambassadors have agreed to await an appointed day to conjointly take some very energetic step. As to Count Guileminot, his instructions do not appear to permit him to go so far, and though he has counselled the Refs Effendi to accept the propositions, of his colleagues, it is not thought that his court, which to be sure, favors in some measure the views of England and Russia respecting Greece, has formally acceeded to the conference oi April 4th, 1926.

 March 1.-The indirect assent given by Austria and Prussia to the proceedings of the ambassadors of Russia and England, IS confined, as it is supposed, on tho part of M. Outteufels and the Prussian Charged .Affaires, M. Milliz, to advising the Refs Effendi to accept the propositions of those two powers. It is inferred that the court of Vienna and Berlin have acceeded, or will accecd to the protocol of the confer enccs of April 4th. All this is to be done to persuade the Porte that they will con- fine themselves to simple demonstrations The armaments continue in the ar. ! goes on witt, rapid pace. At Athens they appear to have taken favorable turn for the Greeks.

 ! April 18th.

 House Of Commons, o'cLOck.-Mr., Wynn, president of the India Board, moved that a writ of elction issue to the borough of New: port, to elect member in the room of the Hon. George Canning, who had accepted the place of first Lord of the Treasury.-[Great cheering from all parts of the House. l-Mr. Wynn then moved an adjournment to the 1st of May, in order to afford time for Mr. Can ming to frame his new cabinet, Mir. Tiernay objected, saying that time enough had been taken to form a new cabinet, and as it was understood that seven of the old members had run a,Oay, and nobody knew when they would return, it was not worth while to wait. The adjournment, however, was carried.

 It is impossible for us. at this distance, to conjecture who will be Mr. Canning's associ- ates. The Times of April 11th says-that he, MT. Canning, having refused to accept the station of Premier, unless with unrestrained authority to form cabinet, had carried his point, and was perfectly free.

 l Lord Granville, the British Ambassador at Paris, is mentioned forthe Foreign Secretary, and Mr. Scarlett as the successor of the Lord

The bill for districting the state, now before the House of Representatives, proposes that there be not less than lS nor more than "A Senators chosen by. the districts-that the Legislature for 1928 district the state for the choice of Senators, and determine the num- Der for each Gistrict-the number of districts to be from to 18, (no town to be divided) to continue until the next census, and to be reg ulated accordingly afterwards. When regu- lated agreeably to the census, no alteration to take place in the districts or number of Sena- tors, oftener than once in ten years. On the first Monday of April, 1880, and annually thereafter, the freemen to choose senators, the candidates residing in the districts. The candidates having plurality of votes to be elected, and should a tie occur, the decision to be left to the House of Representatives.

 In many papers wise speculations are enter ed into in relation to inc resignation of seven of the principal ministers of the British Cabi net-the causes of such resignation, and the probable consequences which may grow out of the measure. The most rational one which we have seen stated is, that Mir. Can ming, the newly elected Premier, does not possess by birth, noble blood, although all seem willing to acknowledge that he possesses ccr- tain qualifcations-Nhether the consequences of patrician or a plebian birth we know not

 ;nb T,u khn Ao1 nrl of his noble opponents. Mir. Canning is, and we presume vii! continue to be, supported in his now and responsible station, not only by the crown, but by the mass ofthe English na- ton. The mighty powers of his mind will not suffer the spleen of band of aristocratc to work to the injury of his country. London papers, to the l6th of April, say that he has already selected a new cabinet, and give the following as the list:-

 Sir John Copely to be Lord Chancellor. Lord Granville to be Foreign Secretary.

 MT. Robinson, (with Peerage) Colonial Secretary.

 Mr. Huskisson Home Secretary, (this not certainly

 Lords Dudley aud Ward, Privy Seal.

 Lord Carlisle, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland. Duke of Dcvonsllire, Lord Chamberlain, (not certainly

 Marquis of Anslesca, Master of the Ord nance.

 Lord Bexley is allowed to come back to the Cabinet.

 The Marquis of Anglesea. We understand, IS likely to be appointed Master General of the Ordnance.

 The new title of Mr. Robinson IS Lord Strathearn.

 The report of the agents ofthe Eagle bank states that nearly all the debts which grew out ofthe ordinary, or honest business of the bank have already been paid; but that fifteen hun dred thousand dollars are yet outstanding,- The agents further state, that they "have reason to believe that great amount of prop erty belonging the debtors has been secreted or withdrawn from the jurisdiction of the state; but as some of the principal debtors are now confined in the state, they are not without expectation that further collections,by compromise or otherwise, will be made. Un- der these circumstances very little, as yet has been collected to constitute fund for divi dend among the creditors of the bank. The agents have not deemed it advisable to avail themselves of the provisions of the act of 1926 which authorizes the superior court to limit the time ofexhibiting claims, and to declare a dividend thereon, believing that the interests 1.-the creditors would be thereby promoted. The sum of the money obtained by fraudulent and illegal means, which has confined hun dreds of cOnvicts in our jails and penitentia- ries, will fall far short, we believe, of the a. mount swindled out of the public by the care less or rillanous conduct of the president of the Eagle Bank

 Counterfeit one dollar notes of the Manhat- ian Bank of New-York, and also of the N. J. State Bank at Newark, payable at the Me chanics' Bank in New Ork, are said to be in circulation. The former are marked with the letters Ii, dated Dec. e6, 1926. The plate is good, and the signatures well calculated to

 -N- ~RH

of Church Music. There have, belleve, aI- ways existed peculiar difficulties in this cOun- try arising from the low state Ofthis rt,which we have reason to fear cannot be immediate ly removed; and they are difficulties which do not exist in relation to the cultivation of any other art or science which is attempted in our country. Our learned men, who are eminent for their acquaintance with other branches of learning, with the exception Ofa very few individuals, know nothing at all of this-we have no professOrshps ;-and schol ars while acquiring an education are led to look upon it as science beneath their notice. Now sir, with difference and respect, Iwould wish to inform our very respectable men of learning, that there is perhaps no science 1 where they would find more room for the ex- ercise of their greatest talents, and their most persevering industry. Butwhile they contin- ue to neglect the cultivation of this delightful art, it can hardly be expected that the music of our churches can be carried to the perfec- ton which it deserves by few individuals, laboring under all the inconyeniences. and struggling against all the difficulties which are thrown in their way by that same neglect ] and indifference; and by the ignorance and stupidity of community at large. Nothing is more common than to hear parents who on other subjects speak and act with proprie ty, make use of such language as this :--"I will send my child to the Singing School, if it will not interfere with his other studies-nay, wish him to learn to sing, but he must spend i no time except the evenings he is at school" Strange doctrine this.-He must learn to sing, but his mind must not be occupied with his music, lest it should interrupt his proficiency in his Geography or his Arithmetic! With the same propriety might he say in relation to other schools, '' He may study Arithmetic, but it must not interfere with his other stud

 ies; or he may learn to read, but he must spend no time about it, lest his mind become completely occupied, and he learn nothing 1 eIsc." Iwould not be understood to recom- mend the study of Music, and to neglect the study of other and more common branches of education; but in the language of Scrip ture, "these ought we to do, and not to leave the other undone."

 But here am aware the objection, want of time, will boldly stand up in my face. What, 1 Sir, do our friends and neighbours want time for doing what they already spend double the time necessary for doing Do they want time to learn to sing, when they spend winter af- ter winter in attending a Singing School merely to get rid of the time which hangs heav- fly on their hands? lift is time they want, answer, time IS the very thing wish to save for them. Are there not very many in most of our towns and parishes, who have spent more hours in Singing Meetings than they ever did in studying Arithmetic ? think there are very many. And I also think every per son well acquainted with Music will agree with me when say that the necessary rules for reading and timing Music, are much more simple in their application than the rules of Arithmetic and those arc all that a mere

 performer need understand.

 But we act as though there were some magic connected with scientific knowledge of music, with which it was dangerous for those not initiated to intermeddle. And some of us seem to suppose that such knowledge of necessity must destroy all taste for other branches oflearning, and still more, all indus l trious habits and inclinations. @

 l But who cannot remember the time when Geography and English Grammar were scarcely thought of as necessary in our com mon schools ?-when person who in study ing Arithmetic had 1" gone as far as the Rule of Three," was considered competent for any business ?-and person who had "been to College" was looked upon as prodigy ?- But now the case is different. Now we think thorough knowledge of English Grammar, Arithmetic, Sc. as necessary requisites for common education; and now almost every neighborhood is furnished with one or more persons of liberal and polite education. And has our country of late been in less four ishing condition than formerly Tor if it has,

THE subscriber being about leaving town.

 A requests all persons having unsettled ac- counts with him, to call and settle the same before the gath inst, as he will leave town on that day. Those indebted will take particu- lar notice. w. H. ADAMS.

 Litchlield. May 2S. 1927.

The time was when l was young and hopeful plant ofnature. In the course of years l became tall, and the birds of the air were happy under my shadow, and re- ] turned me the sweetest notes for the pro- lection afforded them. By the hand of man was cut down, and stript of natures robes, and became an Arch in the Cuthe- drGt ct GIOSgOc, and for upwards of seven hundred years have been cover to the teachers in that sanctuary. also screen ed alike the saint and tue sinner from the stormy blast; but now l am an outcast from the House of God, and have become 2 :, ,ss'.!, ,.. :h U l.a hands of man, and a part Of say 'e..@a5-.5 34~2 been converted into this Snutl-Oox.

 Niles Weekly Register states that an ele- gant broadcloth power loom, of New-York manufacture, was lately shipped for England, for one of the Leeds Factories. Some ma chinery made by MT. Gilbert Brewster,w which had been sent by order to Prussia, has been so much approved of, that he has received fresh orders for the supply of a number of his own machines, and other machinery for the man. ufacture of wool and cotton. The editor re- m arks-" these are new things and pleasant We like this method of exporting provisions We pack up 300 or 1000 dollars worth of -four in small box, and foreigners are made to contribute to the profits of our farmers, who willnot directly receive any thing from then." Brother JOnathan's new cOntrivancess'' go on bravely, and the time is not distant when his workshops will become more celebrated than his old masters, even in England. A MT. M'kcnny was lately married to Mrs. Mary Jackson, both of Harper's Ferry, he being the ladies fifth husband, and she only in her twenty eighth year. What blue beard she must be.

 A gang has been detected in Gainesville, Ohio, in counterfeiting American half dollars, l and Spanish dollars.

 ] A writer in the Charlestown Courier says. that according to an article in the Christian | Advocate, it appears that the city of Charles ton. with about one-sixth of the population I of New \ ork, has contributed three fold more to the American Bible Society than N. York

 The annual amount of ardent spirits con sumed in the United States, is not less than 45,0OO, ,0OO gallons, which supposing the drink ing population to be million, persons would 1 give them an allowance of a pint ofardent spir- its per day.

 Purchases, to the amount of S5O,0OO have been made of wood lands, on the BavOuse 1 Caillou, Black ,S1c. in the vicinity Of La Four che, for the purpose of establishing large ! plantations of sugar cane, for which the soil is remarkably well calculated.

 The ground was covered with snow at Ro- chester, N. Y. on the 9th inst. From various parts of the country we learn that the season is extremely backward.

 The Cheraw S. c. Spectator of the 14th inst. says" A severe frost has nearly des- troyed the gardens, and ice of very consider able thickness was to be seen in various places this morning.

 The capillary lamp is beautiful little in- vention. The small glass tube is fixed in a little metal bowl. with the concave up, for the purpose of floating it in spermiceti oil. By presenting lighted paper to the top of the tube, the air rairiies, the oil rises and is l ignlted, and it continues to burn at the rate of a spoonful and half for i2 or l4 hours, with bright gas like flame. As the ignition proceeds the tube becomes tipped with the ] charcoal which subsequently requires to be cleared away. The defect seems to be that | the thin glass of which the tube is made, ap- pears to be gradually burut off and to scale away. A more uncomfortable material, or a set of the glass tubes accompanying each lamp, and to be readily fixed to them, would make this lamp as perfect as could be desired.

 'Sauc noe from my friends. dinner was given by the citizens of Knoxville Tennessee, to H. L. White, Esq. Senator in Congress, on the 5th nit. at which the following toast was given.

 "By CoI. s. D. Jac0bs.-Andrew Jack son we anxiously hope for the preserva- ton of his life, until his elevation to the Presidential chair, when bis uncomprom- ising honesty, and incorrupti bic integrity, will wither into political non-existence the "hf handed" politicians of the day but should Providence deprive US of him, would it not be well to stretch his skin O. yer drum head, like that of John Ziscas of old, and beat up a crusade against the aggrandizing, patronizing, staterig ght-tram- bling, newspaper-crushing, and billiard ta- { bLe policy of the Administrator. Resolution.-A lad who carries the mail between Poultney and Vcrgennes, Vt. on ar irving at a river from which the bridge had been swept away by recent freshet, raised the mail bag above his head, plunged his horse

MT. SMITH

 The publication in your last weeks paper signed J. Barnes. containing, as it does, little but vague insinuation and scurrility, is justly entitled only to silent contempt. The undersigned think proper however, to submit to the public. through the medium of your next paper, the following brief statement of facts in relation to the subject alluded to. The undersigned did not bring forward the resolutions alluded to, neither had they any agency whatever in originating them, nor did they know that any such measure was con templated, until the resolutions were handed to the chair by another member.

 As to the state of the meeting, it consisted of full average of the number of members usually attending the annual meetings of the Medical Society of the County. The whole number who had been present during the day, with perhaps single exception were in attendance when the subject of the resolutions was discussed, and as has been published from tho records of the Society, voted unan- imously in their favour, "smiies" and other equally authentic sources of information to the contrary notwithstanding.

 WILLIAM BUEL,

 SAMUEL R. CHILDS. Lltchfeld, May 24th, 1927,

Probate Court, May 2i, 1897. HESITATE of JOHN PARISH, late of L Washington, deceased;-

full articles.headline: NOTICE.
full articles.article:
TNIiE subscriber takes this method of in- A forming his friends, and the public gener- ally. that he continues to carry on the TAI LORING BUSINESS in all it's branches at his old stand near the Court House, where all who are dispo=ed to favour him with their custom. can have their garments cut and made in good style. Having acquaintance with some of the best establishments in the state, every thing relative to fashion will be speedi- ly procured. And while he feels grateful for the liberal patronage he has received, he as- sures his customers that nothing shall be wan ting on his part to give general satisfaction in future.

 STEPHEN TROWBRIDGE.

 Litchfeld, May 23, 1927. 4o

into the swollen stream, and swam through On relating his adventures, and being asked why he attempted so dangerous an experi- ment, he replied, "Why there's fine of fifty dollars if we don't deliver the mail in season, and guess they don't get it out of dad this time, and be darn'd to 'em."

with general debility under which he hss suffered for nearly year, caused his death. Ills remains were brought to this town on Saturday last; and on Sunday were followed by his surviving relations, and large com course of friends and neighbours, to the grave. It is not the lot of all men, placed in the same walks of life, tO secure to them selves the warmest love and respect of a large community. This was preeminently the case with Judge Holmes. In peeuniary concerns he has experienced prosperity and diversity; yet he was at all times the same liberal bene- factor of the poor, who were never driven away frem his door empty, and the same pat ron and friend of every enlightened and pub Ilc spirited undertaking Although in his lat- ter years he was not wealthy, yet no man was more willing to give both to public and private benefaciions than himself. The words of inspirations, ''The poor ye shall always have with you," were believed by him to con- tam an important meaning. and we believe he Eever felt disposed to evade this meaning, or shrink from the dutyswhich it enioined.- In every duty in life,--as son,--a hnsband,- tather,-a judge,-a citizen,--he manifested the same amiabe disposition, tempered with stern integrity and love for truth ,-he was atiahie, yet not cOnceited, ,-hospitable, yet not ostentatious,- charitable yet not pharisaical, -pious, yet not hypocritcal. The whole of his character may be summed up in this short, comprehensive sentence, "He was good man ;'-and although the circumstaa- ces of his death were attended with some aggravating incidents, in being called to endure pain, and suffering and death, in small pubic house, and out of the reach of those comforts and sympathies which would have consoled him in his own dwelling. his friends have the consolation of refiecting that. notwithstanding these outward affections he had peace within; and that he gave good as- surance that that Spiri. which had taught him to trust in the Redeemer, was supporting him in his passage through the dark valley and shadow of dcath.''

papers have been received at N. Y. to April 10th, and Liverpool to the f7th.

D'Ofalia, is commanded to make known to the British and French Governments, that it is the in- tention of the Cabinet of Madrid to send an expedition against Mexico to establish the Infant Francisco de Paula as sove- reign. Tho Court is also said to have a still more difficult task to perform, namely, to obtain the concurrence of the Courts of the Tuilleries and St.James, to the meas ure."

 Const0ntinople. March 1O.-Since my last letter, which announced to you the en- ergetic conduct of the new Russian Am bassador relative to the pacification of Greece, no very important change has taken place.

 l The English Ambassador, M. Straitford Canning, has yet received no answer from the Divan to his note of Feb. 9th, and as the conversations of the Refs Effendi to this minister, as we'll as to M. Ribeau- Ipierre, leave little hope of obtaining the consent of the Porte to their propositions, it is reported that the two Ambassadors have agreed to await an appointed day to conjointly take some very energetic step. As to Count Guileminot, his instructions do not appear to permit him to go so far, and though he has counselled the Refs Effendi to accept the propositions, of his colleagues, it is not thought that his court, which to be sure, favors in some measure the views of England and Russia respecting Greece, has formally acceeded to the conference oi April 4th, 1926.

 March 1.-The indirect assent given by Austria and Prussia to the proceedings of the ambassadors of Russia and England, IS confined, as it is supposed, on tho part of M. Outteufels and the Prussian Charged .Affaires, M. Milliz, to advising the Refs Effendi to accept the propositions of those two powers. It is inferred that the court of Vienna and Berlin have acceeded, or will accecd to the protocol of the confer enccs of April 4th. All this is to be done to persuade the Porte that they will con- fine themselves to simple demonstrations The armaments continue in the ar. ! goes on witt, rapid pace. At Athens they appear to have taken favorable turn for the Greeks.

 ! April 18th.

 House Of Commons, o'cLOck.-Mr., Wynn, president of the India Board, moved that a writ of elction issue to the borough of New: port, to elect member in the room of the Hon. George Canning, who had accepted the place of first Lord of the Treasury.-[Great cheering from all parts of the House. l-Mr. Wynn then moved an adjournment to the 1st of May, in order to afford time for Mr. Can ming to frame his new cabinet, Mir. Tiernay objected, saying that time enough had been taken to form a new cabinet, and as it was understood that seven of the old members had run a,Oay, and nobody knew when they would return, it was not worth while to wait. The adjournment, however, was carried.

 It is impossible for us. at this distance, to conjecture who will be Mr. Canning's associ- ates. The Times of April 11th says-that he, MT. Canning, having refused to accept the station of Premier, unless with unrestrained authority to form cabinet, had carried his point, and was perfectly free.

 l Lord Granville, the British Ambassador at Paris, is mentioned forthe Foreign Secretary, and Mr. Scarlett as the successor of the Lord

The bill for districting the state, now before the House of Representatives, proposes that there be not less than lS nor more than "A Senators chosen by. the districts-that the Legislature for 1928 district the state for the choice of Senators, and determine the num- Der for each Gistrict-the number of districts to be from to 18, (no town to be divided) to continue until the next census, and to be reg ulated accordingly afterwards. When regu- lated agreeably to the census, no alteration to take place in the districts or number of Sena- tors, oftener than once in ten years. On the first Monday of April, 1880, and annually thereafter, the freemen to choose senators, the candidates residing in the districts. The candidates having plurality of votes to be elected, and should a tie occur, the decision to be left to the House of Representatives.

 In many papers wise speculations are enter ed into in relation to inc resignation of seven of the principal ministers of the British Cabi net-the causes of such resignation, and the probable consequences which may grow out of the measure. The most rational one which we have seen stated is, that Mir. Can ming, the newly elected Premier, does not possess by birth, noble blood, although all seem willing to acknowledge that he possesses ccr- tain qualifcations-Nhether the consequences of patrician or a plebian birth we know not

 ;nb T,u khn Ao1 nrl of his noble opponents. Mir. Canning is, and we presume vii! continue to be, supported in his now and responsible station, not only by the crown, but by the mass ofthe English na- ton. The mighty powers of his mind will not suffer the spleen of band of aristocratc to work to the injury of his country. London papers, to the l6th of April, say that he has already selected a new cabinet, and give the following as the list:-

 Sir John Copely to be Lord Chancellor. Lord Granville to be Foreign Secretary.

 MT. Robinson, (with Peerage) Colonial Secretary.

 Mr. Huskisson Home Secretary, (this not certainly

 Lords Dudley aud Ward, Privy Seal.

 Lord Carlisle, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland. Duke of Dcvonsllire, Lord Chamberlain, (not certainly

 Marquis of Anslesca, Master of the Ord nance.

 Lord Bexley is allowed to come back to the Cabinet.

 The Marquis of Anglesea. We understand, IS likely to be appointed Master General of the Ordnance.

 The new title of Mr. Robinson IS Lord Strathearn.

 The report of the agents ofthe Eagle bank states that nearly all the debts which grew out ofthe ordinary, or honest business of the bank have already been paid; but that fifteen hun dred thousand dollars are yet outstanding,- The agents further state, that they "have reason to believe that great amount of prop erty belonging the debtors has been secreted or withdrawn from the jurisdiction of the state; but as some of the principal debtors are now confined in the state, they are not without expectation that further collections,by compromise or otherwise, will be made. Un- der these circumstances very little, as yet has been collected to constitute fund for divi dend among the creditors of the bank. The agents have not deemed it advisable to avail themselves of the provisions of the act of 1926 which authorizes the superior court to limit the time ofexhibiting claims, and to declare a dividend thereon, believing that the interests 1.-the creditors would be thereby promoted. The sum of the money obtained by fraudulent and illegal means, which has confined hun dreds of cOnvicts in our jails and penitentia- ries, will fall far short, we believe, of the a. mount swindled out of the public by the care less or rillanous conduct of the president of the Eagle Bank

 Counterfeit one dollar notes of the Manhat- ian Bank of New-York, and also of the N. J. State Bank at Newark, payable at the Me chanics' Bank in New Ork, are said to be in circulation. The former are marked with the letters Ii, dated Dec. e6, 1926. The plate is good, and the signatures well calculated to

full articles.headline: FOR THE COUNTY pUsr.
full articles.article:
of Church Music. There have, belleve, aI- ways existed peculiar difficulties in this cOun- try arising from the low state Ofthis rt,which we have reason to fear cannot be immediate ly removed; and they are difficulties which do not exist in relation to the cultivation of any other art or science which is attempted in our country. Our learned men, who are eminent for their acquaintance with other branches of learning, with the exception Ofa very few individuals, know nothing at all of this-we have no professOrshps ;-and schol ars while acquiring an education are led to look upon it as science beneath their notice. Now sir, with difference and respect, Iwould wish to inform our very respectable men of learning, that there is perhaps no science 1 where they would find more room for the ex- ercise of their greatest talents, and their most persevering industry. Butwhile they contin- ue to neglect the cultivation of this delightful art, it can hardly be expected that the music of our churches can be carried to the perfec- ton which it deserves by few individuals, laboring under all the inconyeniences. and struggling against all the difficulties which are thrown in their way by that same neglect ] and indifference; and by the ignorance and stupidity of community at large. Nothing is more common than to hear parents who on other subjects speak and act with proprie ty, make use of such language as this :--"I will send my child to the Singing School, if it will not interfere with his other studies-nay, wish him to learn to sing, but he must spend i no time except the evenings he is at school" Strange doctrine this.-He must learn to sing, but his mind must not be occupied with his music, lest it should interrupt his proficiency in his Geography or his Arithmetic! With the same propriety might he say in relation to other schools, '' He may study Arithmetic, but it must not interfere with his other stud

 ies; or he may learn to read, but he must spend no time about it, lest his mind become completely occupied, and he learn nothing 1 eIsc." Iwould not be understood to recom- mend the study of Music, and to neglect the study of other and more common branches of education; but in the language of Scrip ture, "these ought we to do, and not to leave the other undone."

 But here am aware the objection, want of time, will boldly stand up in my face. What, 1 Sir, do our friends and neighbours want time for doing what they already spend double the time necessary for doing Do they want time to learn to sing, when they spend winter af- ter winter in attending a Singing School merely to get rid of the time which hangs heav- fly on their hands? lift is time they want, answer, time IS the very thing wish to save for them. Are there not very many in most of our towns and parishes, who have spent more hours in Singing Meetings than they ever did in studying Arithmetic ? think there are very many. And I also think every per son well acquainted with Music will agree with me when say that the necessary rules for reading and timing Music, are much more simple in their application than the rules of Arithmetic and those arc all that a mere

 performer need understand.

 But we act as though there were some magic connected with scientific knowledge of music, with which it was dangerous for those not initiated to intermeddle. And some of us seem to suppose that such knowledge of necessity must destroy all taste for other branches oflearning, and still more, all indus l trious habits and inclinations. @

 l But who cannot remember the time when Geography and English Grammar were scarcely thought of as necessary in our com mon schools ?-when person who in study ing Arithmetic had 1" gone as far as the Rule of Three," was considered competent for any business ?-and person who had "been to College" was looked upon as prodigy ?- But now the case is different. Now we think thorough knowledge of English Grammar, Arithmetic, Sc. as necessary requisites for common education; and now almost every neighborhood is furnished with one or more persons of liberal and polite education. And has our country of late been in less four ishing condition than formerly Tor if it has,

THE subscriber being about leaving town.

 A requests all persons having unsettled ac- counts with him, to call and settle the same before the gath inst, as he will leave town on that day. Those indebted will take particu- lar notice. w. H. ADAMS.

 Litchlield. May 2S. 1927.

The time was when l was young and hopeful plant ofnature. In the course of years l became tall, and the birds of the air were happy under my shadow, and re- ] turned me the sweetest notes for the pro- lection afforded them. By the hand of man was cut down, and stript of natures robes, and became an Arch in the Cuthe- drGt ct GIOSgOc, and for upwards of seven hundred years have been cover to the teachers in that sanctuary. also screen ed alike the saint and tue sinner from the stormy blast; but now l am an outcast from the House of God, and have become 2 :, ,ss'.!, ,.. :h U l.a hands of man, and a part Of say 'e..@a5-.5 34~2 been converted into this Snutl-Oox.

 Niles Weekly Register states that an ele- gant broadcloth power loom, of New-York manufacture, was lately shipped for England, for one of the Leeds Factories. Some ma chinery made by MT. Gilbert Brewster,w which had been sent by order to Prussia, has been so much approved of, that he has received fresh orders for the supply of a number of his own machines, and other machinery for the man. ufacture of wool and cotton. The editor re- m arks-" these are new things and pleasant We like this method of exporting provisions We pack up 300 or 1000 dollars worth of -four in small box, and foreigners are made to contribute to the profits of our farmers, who willnot directly receive any thing from then." Brother JOnathan's new cOntrivancess'' go on bravely, and the time is not distant when his workshops will become more celebrated than his old masters, even in England. A MT. M'kcnny was lately married to Mrs. Mary Jackson, both of Harper's Ferry, he being the ladies fifth husband, and she only in her twenty eighth year. What blue beard she must be.

 A gang has been detected in Gainesville, Ohio, in counterfeiting American half dollars, l and Spanish dollars.

 ] A writer in the Charlestown Courier says. that according to an article in the Christian | Advocate, it appears that the city of Charles ton. with about one-sixth of the population I of New \ ork, has contributed three fold more to the American Bible Society than N. York

 The annual amount of ardent spirits con sumed in the United States, is not less than 45,0OO, ,0OO gallons, which supposing the drink ing population to be million, persons would 1 give them an allowance of a pint ofardent spir- its per day.

 Purchases, to the amount of S5O,0OO have been made of wood lands, on the BavOuse 1 Caillou, Black ,S1c. in the vicinity Of La Four che, for the purpose of establishing large ! plantations of sugar cane, for which the soil is remarkably well calculated.

 The ground was covered with snow at Ro- chester, N. Y. on the 9th inst. From various parts of the country we learn that the season is extremely backward.

 The Cheraw S. c. Spectator of the 14th inst. says" A severe frost has nearly des- troyed the gardens, and ice of very consider able thickness was to be seen in various places this morning.

 The capillary lamp is beautiful little in- vention. The small glass tube is fixed in a little metal bowl. with the concave up, for the purpose of floating it in spermiceti oil. By presenting lighted paper to the top of the tube, the air rairiies, the oil rises and is l ignlted, and it continues to burn at the rate of a spoonful and half for i2 or l4 hours, with bright gas like flame. As the ignition proceeds the tube becomes tipped with the ] charcoal which subsequently requires to be cleared away. The defect seems to be that | the thin glass of which the tube is made, ap- pears to be gradually burut off and to scale away. A more uncomfortable material, or a set of the glass tubes accompanying each lamp, and to be readily fixed to them, would make this lamp as perfect as could be desired.

Resolution.-A lad who carries the mail between Poultney and Vcrgennes, Vt. on ar irving at a river from which the bridge had been swept away by recent freshet, raised the mail bag above his head, plunged his horse

MT. SMITH

 The publication in your last weeks paper signed J. Barnes. containing, as it does, little but vague insinuation and scurrility, is justly entitled only to silent contempt. The undersigned think proper however, to submit to the public. through the medium of your next paper, the following brief statement of facts in relation to the subject alluded to. The undersigned did not bring forward the resolutions alluded to, neither had they any agency whatever in originating them, nor did they know that any such measure was con templated, until the resolutions were handed to the chair by another member.

 As to the state of the meeting, it consisted of full average of the number of members usually attending the annual meetings of the Medical Society of the County. The whole number who had been present during the day, with perhaps single exception were in attendance when the subject of the resolutions was discussed, and as has been published from tho records of the Society, voted unan- imously in their favour, "smiies" and other equally authentic sources of information to the contrary notwithstanding.

 WILLIAM BUEL,

 SAMUEL R. CHILDS. Lltchfeld, May 24th, 1927,
